fields.Title of Contribution: <p><span>Writers and/as Bodies of Water in </span>Antje Rávik Strubel’s novel In the Forest of the Human Heart (2016)</p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>2021 German Book Prize winner, Antje Rávik Strubel has stated that her three unrelated novels from 2008, 2011 and 2016 are a trilogy. This article shows how this trilogy necessarily ends with a focus on writers, because writers steer readers to places of transformation, connected to water. Applying Jack Halberstam’s </span><span>Queer Art of Failure</span><span> (2011) and Strubel’s 2013 lecture on writing, “Segeltörn unter rätselhaftem Himmel,” in which Strubel demarcates her call for writing to whirl, blur and confuse, this article explains the importance of water and the metaphor of kayaking for Strubel’s writerly figures. Analyses of Strubel’s writerly craft, of the advantages of getting lost and following detours—especially paddling away from shore, reveal this novel’s journey as a mosaic. Significantly, this article also shows how the writer René is central in the novel and linked with the writer Katt. </span></p>

attachments.filename: Norman. Studies in 20th21stCent Lit. submission.  Writers and Bodies of Water .docx
